item.title: Forget about those real leaves you have to deal this autumn with Leaf Blower Co, which arrives later this month
item.content:encoded:
There are many words that could be said, and I'll attempt to say a few of them here, on the gamification of both menial labour and tasks, but it is always fascinating to me when a new game crops up that somehow makes me go "oh, sure, why not!" Today that applies to a game called Leaf Blower Co., which is a simulation game about exactly what you'd expect (blowing leaves) and I suppose not what you expect (blowing paper boats and coconuts).

I bring your attention to Leaf Blower Co. because it just released a release date - November 17th, later this month, very seasonally appropriate - but also because of how specific a task it is. Said task is one that is, as many of these games often are, satisfying. Hurray, no more leaves on my front lawn, and I did so by blowing them around, what fun! It is also the kind of task that many of us who face this problem will inevitably put off until it is not so putoffable.

Here though, there is an opportunity to do it recreationally, without the requirement of physical effort, and no so to speak real-world punishment (messy lawn your neighbour doesn't like and moans about at you) for not finishing or even starting it.

You don't have to just blow the leaves in Leaf Blower Co. You can jump in them, of course, or burn them, rake them, suck them up, magnetise them. Not entirely sure how that last one works, but the world of video game logic is infinitely confusing, so we'll put that to the side. There are secrets to discover too apparently, one of the trailers on Steam shows that you can, quite quietly, play a bunch of different horns that all toot one note by blowing into them with your blower.

There is some of that ickiness that can come with these games, in that the goal is to build up your leaf blowing business. I think games like these often end up becoming so popular because they are (almost) tangible ways to accomplish these tasks that in reality we just might not be able to because of external factors like mental and physical health, or a simple lack of time due to feeding that disgusting beast called capitalism. So, I don't entirely judge games like Leaf Blower Co., I do think it looks like a relaxing time, but I wonder how we can reframe, or even just frame, ideas of what relaxing is or could be.

Anyway, as mentioned, Leaf Blower Co. is out November 17th, and you can wishlist it on Steam here.

item.title: I Regret To Report ‚ÄòGrand Theft Cthulhu‚Äô On Game Pass Just Ain‚Äôt Good
item.content:encoded:
I often have to play a game for a few hours before I feel confident in saying I liked it or didn‚Äôt like it. Before I can say this is good or this is bad. Sometimes you play a game that, within 20 minutes or less, makes it clear that it ain‚Äôt very good. Sadly, Dead Static Drive was one of those games.

Dead Static Drive has been in some form of development for nearly a decade and has repeatedly gone viral online thanks to its eye-catching art style. And now the isometric survival horror game is out on Xbox, PC, and Game Pass. Often marketed as ‚ÄúGrand Theft Cthulu,‚Äù Dead Static Drive has you stealing cars, completing missions, and exploring a monster-infested world that provides a lot of freedom to go where you want to go while trying to gather the supplies you need to stay alive. It‚Äôs a cool idea, for sure, but it never comes together. Most of this game doesn‚Äôt really work, and with the exception of Dead Static Drive‚Äòs wonderful low-poly art style, there‚Äôs little about this game that I enjoyed.

The biggest issue I encountered is how horrible it feels to drive cars in the newly released game. In something describing itself as Grand Theft Chthulu, I expected the cars to handle well and feel fun to drive around desolate cities and highways. Nope! No matter what camera or controller settings I changed, driving in Dead Static Drive is a mess. I never felt in control of any vehicle I entered, and getting around corners without crashing proved to be the biggest challenge. I‚Äôm also baffled by the decision not to include any engine noises. The first time I got into a car and drove off, I assumed the game had bugged out and the car should be making noise. Restarted, tried a different car, and nope. Nothing. Silence. I looked at other people‚Äôs gameplay and it turns out that this isn‚Äôt a bug, but a design choice. And it‚Äôs odd! This robs the different cars you encounter of a lot of the personality and makes the game feel unfinished.

A lot of this game feels unfinished, though, so that‚Äôs probably why I assumed the missing audio was a bug at first. Combat is a slog, animations are clunky, quests break all the time, and NPCs get stuck on geometry. The inventory screen seems half-finished, missing features like ‚ÄúQuick Move‚Äù which makes managing all the gubbins you find annoying as heck on a controller. Characters also don‚Äôt have voice lines, which could have been fine, but in a game where cars make no noise beyond tire squeals and the world around you is empty, it just leads to Dead Static Drive being a boring experience.

After about three hours of playing Dead Static Drive, I pulled over and got out. It‚Äôs a shame because the world looks amazing, and I like the premise a lot, but what‚Äôs here just isn‚Äôt worth any more time.

item.title: If You‚Äôve Finally Run Out Of Stuff To Do In Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3, How About A New Campaign?
item.content:encoded:
Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 is an incredibly dense RPG, and I‚Äôm sure there are still players who have yet to see everything in Larian Studio‚Äôs Dungeons & Dragons adventure. However, for the sickos who have been combing through the game for two years and wish they had a reason to go back to it, a group of dedicated fan modders is working on what is essentially the expansion Larian chose not to make. 

‚ÄúPath to Menzoberranzan‚Äù is an entirely fan-made campaign separate from the story and characters of Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3. Around 130 modders are working on this original tale. Though the full campaign is still far off, the alpha is projected to launch in the ‚Äúfirst half of 2026,‚Äù and will include the mod‚Äôs prologue chapter. As the name suggests, the mod‚Äôs campaign will take players to Menzoberranzan, a prominent Drow city in the fantastical world of Faer√ªn. Even if you‚Äôre a casual Forgotten Realms fan, you might have heard about the city from Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 companion Minthara, who originated from the city before becoming a pawn of the Absolute. 

Though it remains to be seen if the campaign will have any overt references to the main game‚Äôs crew, ‚ÄúPath to Menzoberranzan‚Äù will feature an entirely new cast of characters, each with an original backstory and voice acting. While development is ongoing, the team is still actively recruiting team members, auditioning voice actors, and providing semi-regular updates on its Discord server. So if you‚Äôre looking for something to do while you wait for whatever Larian is working on next, here‚Äôs another Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 project to distract you.

Despite Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3‚Äôs resounding success, Larian seems to be done with the series and is instead working on two new projects. We don‚Äôt know what either of them is yet, but the team is likely much further along than the ideation phase it was in when Larian first started discussing these games last year. Despite moving on from the game, Larian put out some massive patches and free updates for Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3, so if you haven‚Äôt played it since launch, there‚Äôs plenty new to see.

item.title: Planet Zoo fans get massive news as sequel plans emerge on sixth anniversary
item.content:encoded:
It's hard to believe Planet Zoo - still the best of developer Frontier's modern-day management sims - is six years old. But six it is, and today's birthday celebrations have brought major news, confirming a sequel is on the way.

Planet Zoo launched back in November 2019, bringing the striking presentation and rich customisation of its sister game, Planet Coaster, to the world of zoo management. It was brilliant stuff; gorgeous (just look at those animals!) but with a rock-solid management core. In the six years since, Planet Zoo has received 20 expansion packs - adding new animals, new campaign scenarios, and new themed scenery - and it's even come to consoles too.

But there's still more in store for Planet Zoo, as teased in the game's newly released sixth anniversary trailer. It concludes with a ticker counting up through the years from 2019 to 2026, after which all but one number fades away - the number two. And if the implication wasn't obvious enough, Frontier made a more explicit announcement on its website.

"Since we launched Planet Zoo back in 2019 we've been blown away by the creativity, passion and dedication of you, the community," the studio wrote. "But what does the future hold? Well, today we are delighted to reveal that we are hard at work on a sequel to Planet Zoo! We're really excited about this project, and we look forward to sharing more with you next year!"

It's not entirely clear if Planet Zoo 2 is launching next year, or if that's purely when Frontier will start talking about it, but it'll certainly be interesting to see how the studio plans to meaningfully build on the already pretty definitive first game, particularly after its disappointing Planet Coaster sequel. Here's hoping it can do the excellent original proud! And also for flying birds.

item.title: Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 Path to Menzoberranzan Mod to Get First Playable Alpha By June 2026
item.content:encoded:
While the Baldur's Gate 3 modding scene might not be quite as thriving as that of a Bethesda game like Skyrim, there are still a couple of major projects to follow, such as the Path to Menzoberranzan mod. Modder Lotrich, with the help of over 1,300 Patreon supporters, has established a team of more than 130 contributors.

According to a project update shared this week on the Path to Menzoberranzan Discord channel, the team operates under a centralized structure. There is a group of project directors for each branch of development, and each project director is assisted by leads (coordinators) and seniors, who help oversee project contributors across different departments.

While the full release of the Baldur's Gate 3 mod is still years away, the first playable Alpha is estimated to be available in the first half of 2026. The team said it will include the game's prologue, which should be similar in scope to the Nautiloid of BG3. Over time, more updates will be released to introduce new locations and advance the narrative. The extent of these updates will depend on feedback and the feasibility of implementation. Path to Menzoberranzan reportedly features many interconnected storylines, and the creators want users to experience a satisfying portion of the story with each new update.

As Forgotten Realms experts will have already surmised from the title, the mod adds an entirely new standalone adventure focused on the bright mercantile city of Athkatla and the dark and perilous nature of the Underdark, all the way to the legendary capital of the Drow.

Throughout the story, which spans three acts like Baldur's Gate 3, players will revisit areas from Baldur's Gate 2: Shadows of Amn while also exploring entirely new lands. The campaign is set to feature a new protagonist with a new personal quest and up to 8 brand-new companions, each with their own personal agendas and some of whom will be romanceable.

In Act I, players will visit Athkatla, shop at iconic places like the Adventurer Mart, and explore the long-abandoned dungeon once occupied by the malicious mage Jon Irenicus. In Act II, the player will begin their journey to the titular location, Menzoberranzan, and Act III will feature the drow city itself.

The Path to Menzoberranzan modding team also promised the following features:

  • Fully voiced companions and world NPCs‚Äîno AI-generated voiceovers;
  • Custom concept art and 3D assets as needed;
  • Handcrafted visual style for Menzoberranzan, built from scratch;
  • Multiple side quests on top of the main overarching story;
  • New items, outfits, NPC models;
  • Original musical theme.

Another large-scale Baldur's Gate 3 mod, 'The Grand Theater - Sell your Lute to the Devil', is currently 25% complete, according to its creators. If you're instead looking for a mod that lets you play against your friends, the Versus mode is the one to get.

item.title: The hottest trend in speedrunning is flipping a coin
item.content:encoded:
Unfair Flips is a game about flipping a coin. And despite being designed around random chance, it has a vibrant speedrunning community, racing to see who can get to 10 heads the fastest.

That‚Äôs the only goal. You earn money with each heads and can spend that on four things: a more valuable coin, a combo multiplier for heads streaks, a faster flip time, and an increased heads chance, which starts at 20 percent and maxes out at 60 percent. When you get lucky enough, you flip 10 heads. Until then, the only thing you can do is keep flipping the coin. The current world record took 96 flips and two minutes and 52 seconds by a speedrunner who goes by ravspect. It was, he says, ‚Äúnearly complete luck.‚Äù

But only nearly. The perfect run would essentially be entirely good fortune ‚Äî it is hypothetically possible for someone to load the game and flip 10 heads in a row instantly, ending it in about 20 seconds. The odds of this are a hair under one in 20 million. But the thing about probability is that if enough players try for long enough, it eventually becomes statistically likely. Until then, there are a few things that can give a runner an edge, predominantly around upgrade strategy. A Discord community that originally grew up around some of developer Heather Flowers‚Äô earlier games now has channels dedicated to figuring out the perfect approach. ‚ÄúTalking about the ‚Äònuance‚Äô of flipping a coin might sound crazy, but they were a massive help,‚Äù says ravspect.

One of these community number crunchers, Laika, made a spreadsheet calculating how much money you make depending on combo multiplier and coin value. ‚ÄúI hoped it would help us understand the game better and to develop the best strategy for buying upgrades,‚Äù she says, but tells me so far the only concrete discovery is that it‚Äôs not worth it to buy a second combo multiplier before upgrading the coin twice. In other words, Unfair Flips is not a solved game.

Not without using additional software, anyway. But a player called Four spent about 20 hours in a single weekend to prove that it‚Äôs possible to force a perfect run by cracking the random number generator seed to find one where it‚Äôs predetermined that the coin will land heads 10 times. An alternative option would be to figure out the perfect time to start flipping by using software to ‚Äúwatch‚Äù the figure in the background sip their drink, since this is also partially randomized. (The figure‚Äôs name is Gar, and the drink is milk, although you won‚Äôt find these details in the game, which is about flipping a coin and only flipping a coin.) It‚Äôs estimated that this would take ‚Äúdays or weeks,‚Äù but since the speedrun timer only begins on the first flip, the run itself would be under 20 seconds.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre literally just rawdogging random chance.‚Äù

A more concrete tactic than obsessively watching a masked man drink milk is multi-instancing. Players open multiple versions of the game after their first heads, and if none of those flip heads, they can try again by beginning the quit-out process in the original version and then canceling it by instead muting and unmuting the game, which resets the save. ‚ÄúThis process takes like three to four minutes if you‚Äôre really good at the tech,‚Äù says Flowers. These runs are listed separately, and the world record is currently 2:51, a single second faster than ravspect‚Äôs pure-luck world record.

Unfair Flips is a game that very directly addresses our relationship to probability as humans and within the games industry. ‚ÄúIt is saying, how little of a game can somebody make while still keeping that same level of compulsion to continue playing?‚Äù Flowers tells me. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very much inspired by other gambling games that have come out in the past few years and reductio ad absurdum ‚Äî making the smallest, most absurd version.‚Äù
There isn‚Äôt supposed to be a way to cheat the randomness inherent in the game. ‚ÄúI think the line that people latch onto is ‚ÄòThere is no way to beat these odds. There is only time,‚Äô‚Äù says Flowers. ‚ÄúI was wrong.‚Äù

Although Flowers says she didn‚Äôt expect speedruns to take off, she thinks runners get her design philosophy. ‚ÄúI think everybody in that community is doing it because they know that it‚Äôs really funny to speedrun this game in particular, because you‚Äôre literally just rawdogging random chance.‚Äù It‚Äôs a sentiment echoed to me by most of the runners I spoke to who talked about how they first got into the game. ‚ÄúThere is just something very silly about speedrunning coin flipping and without some silliness life would be very boring,‚Äù says Laika.

There are other speedrunning categories. The game actually has five endings. When you‚Äôve flipped nine heads, it randomly decides whether you‚Äôd normally flip heads again using the percentage chance you‚Äôre currently at. Then, if so, it decides which ending you‚Äôll get. The leaderboard for the ‚ÄúAll Endings‚Äù category has a single entry, a seven-hour run by enbyzee.

‚Äú[It] nearly broke me,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never been mentally battered by a speedrun as much as [that one]. Getting multiple streaks of nine heads in a row only to have tails come up on the 10th. Getting multiple endings I already had when I just needed the last unique ending to finish the run. It was absolutely brutal.‚Äù Although she‚Äôs done long speedruns before, they always have a lot going on, keeping things fresh and interesting. Unfair Flips does not. ‚ÄúI pressed the spacebar over 20,000 times during that run.‚Äù

After five hours and four unique endings playing alone, enbyzee took a quick break, considered quitting, and decided to continue on stream instead. A little over 90 minutes later she got the last ending she needed. ‚ÄúI wanted to scream and cry when it happened. My sister actually called me and told me off for being too loud but I didn‚Äôt care because it was over.‚Äù

‚ÄúI pressed the spacebar over 20,000 times during that run.‚Äù

Ravspect adds that ‚Äúhitting those 10 heads feels just as amazing on your first playthrough as it does on your 100th.‚Äù The community comes together in search of that feeling on Flippin‚Äô Fridays. Every other week, ‚Äúwe connect, share our passion for this weird little speedrun, and just have a good time,‚Äù says Laika. One recent Friday, MsTruffles was one of the runners trying to improve her personal best while streaming to the community. In her first-ever session running the game, she set the then-world record at eight minutes and 20 seconds, the first sub-10-minute run. Since then, ‚ÄúI still haven‚Äôt been lucky enough to improve my time, even after about a hundred attempts,‚Äù she says.

She also adds that Flippin‚Äô Fridays are a good opportunity to bring in new runners. ‚ÄúThis is such an accessible game to speedrun because you don‚Äôt need to learn difficult tricks, practice hard glitches, or remember complicated routing,‚Äù says Laika. ‚ÄúYou just flip.‚Äù

item.title: The Sims 4 gets a laundry list of much needed, community-voted fixes to get the game back in ship shape again
item.content:encoded:
More fixes than you can shake a stick at!

It has not been a good time for Simmers recently, and that's not even touching the recent controversial private buyout that has led to a creator exodus. The Sims 4, for a while now, has been riddled with bugs that simply make it difficult to play, prompting Maxis to outline a quality of life roadmap in September. Part of said roadmap was delivered yesterday in a big update that introduced more than 150 community-voted fixes, as well as some free goodies!

First, the goodies. These are a collection inspired by West Africa to use in both the Create a Sim and build mode. It was made in partnership with the Pan African Gaming Group as well as some Simmers with "with direct connections to West African countries and lived experiences across the Black diaspora in the UK and North America," according to a separate news post about the collection.

You'll find new items like an Okuta Lamp with Woven Shade, an √åtura Cushion, your Sims will now be able to cook dishes like Jollof Rice and Chicken Drumsticks, and there's new West African inspired fashion pieces like a "vibrant jumpsuit, bold patterned shirts, and a playful, printed dress for Toddlers and Children." Neat stuff!

Now, some of those fixes. If you're the kind of Simmer that likes to make your Sims woo-hoo up a family, inherited features should show up in the kids more, like if two Sims have big ears, the kid should too - though there might still be some differences occasionally, just not egregiously so.

There's also been an issue where Sims might put things like books or food items into something like a Sticker Storage Box rather than their more logically assigned homes (shelf, fridge), and that's been fixed. One issue that surely tickled man that saw Sims wearing hats while in their nude outfits has been fixed, though I must admit this one mostly feels like a shame. Forcibly make Sims wear hats while naked! It's funny!

And you can comfortably marry one Sim to another without fear of any fashion faux pas, as an issue where guests would wear random or work outfits if one wasn't chosen for them has been fixed too.

It's a long list of fixes, you can check out the full thing here, which covers mostly the base game, but a lot of different packs too.

No one likes contaminated water, so it's best you fix things up when you find out the water supply is tainted in Arc Raiders. The Source of the Contamination quest asks you to figure out what's causing the issue--and while it may seem pretty simple at a glance, it can be a little tricky to figure out the exact spot where things are going wrong with the water. Below, we'll fill you in on where to find the Flood Spill Intake on the Dam Battlegrounds map and how to solve this mystery.

Be aware that you don't need to extract with any items during this quest. Since you'll merely need to visit the location below and interact with an item, it's not a bad idea to handle things with a free loadout so you're not risking any of your hard-earned resources while exploring here.

Where to find the Flood Spill Intake at the Water Treatment Center

The Water Treatment Center is found just to the left of the middle of the Dam Battlegrounds map. It's a popular spot where a lot of raiders tend to visit to loot and fight, so it's probably best for you to approach it from the swamp if you're trying to keep things quiet. This is also a good call in general since the Flood Spill Intake is on the exterior of this POI.

The Flood Spill Intake is on the northern part of the Water Treatment Center facing toward the swamp. It's not too hard to spot as you approach.

You'll know you've reached the right spot when you see concrete walls containing polluted water. Once you've reached this location, make your way down into the gross water.

In the water will be a barrel, which happens to be the source of the contamination you're searching for. Interact with this suspicious object to defuse it. This completes the quest.

You can now leave the raid by using the Central Swamp Lift to the north. However, while you're here, it's a good time to peruse the various structures in the swamp for loot or check around for mushrooms, the latter of which can be found growing on trees all around this area. You'll need at least twelve of them to complete all of Scrappy's upgrades back in Speranza, so you might as well start collecting them, considering that they're fairly hard to come by.

Next up, you'll need to complete a quest called Switching the Supply. You can also check out our full Arc Raiders quest list to find out what else you'll need to handle while exploring topside.

Battlefield 6 has mostly been a hit since its launch early in October, but chief among its players' concerns have been its arduous challenges. Fortunately, Battlefield Studios has been tracking the conversations regarding these tasks, as well as weapon- and mode-specific assignments, and is rolling out changes to streamline them.

Announced on November 5, Battlefield 6 is receiving a significant overhaul to challenges, one which drastically shortens the vast majority of their requirements to "make them more achievable within a reasonable session length."

As an example, Battlefield Studios cites how it has reduced the amount of required revives for a Support class challenge from 200 to 60. An example of of a streamlined weapon assignment showed that players would only need to inflict 3,000 damage as opposed to the previous requirement of 10,000 damage.

Additionally, mode-specific challenges have become more "standardized." Tasks that once needed five wins to accomplish them now only require two wins, and objective kills needed to complete a challenge have been similarly brought much lower than before.

These changes follow an update that increased experience points gained at the end of matches as well as lowered the threshold for early weapon-attachment ranks. Across the board, these tweaks should make it much easier for players to log in, play a handful of matches, and rank up much more efficiently in shorter play sessions.

Changes like these, including ones to the more advanced and intensive Expert and Master challenges, are currently rolling out and more are on the way, with details on the rollout to come.

item.title: 'Collect the data and share the data:' How can game companies support women with leadership ambitions?
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

November 5, 2025

4 Min Read

Why aren't there more women in leadership roles within the game industry and what is the solution? It's a question former Sony Santa Monica director of product development, Meghan Morgan Juinio, and Gearbox Montreal executive producer Fleur Marty grappled with during an on-stage conversation at Gamescom Asia x Thailand Game Show. 

First, Juinio provided some context to explain why answering that question is so important. She noted that, according to the Entertainment Software Association's latest 'Annual Facts' report on the U.S. video game industry, around 205 million Americans currently play video games‚Äîand 47 percent of those players identified as women. 

But how many women are building video games?

The latest GDC State of the Industry survey found that around 25 percent of developers identified as women. Discussing that data, Juinio questioned how many of those respondents were game directors or studio heads? How many are executives sitting at the top of the table, making decisions about which titles get funded? 

"I think over the past five to ten years, collectively around the world, we've put a great amount of effort and energy into bringing more girls into STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). We've created more pathways for girls in high school and university to have mentorship and internship programs that create pathways for entry-level roles in the game industry," said Juinio. 

Related:Sumo Group-owned outsourcing studio Atomhawk closes Canadian branch

"We want to continue that, but I believe this is a 'yes and' conversation here. So, now what? How do we bring more women along to influence the content that gets into the hand of the players?" 

To find out, I took advantage of a Q&A session to ask Juinio and Marty how major publishers and studios‚Äîsuch as the ones that promoted them into senior positions‚Äîcan take practical steps to help women who wish to pursue leadership roles? 

"If you don't ask the question you'll never know"

Juinio said there are many opportunities for companies to put their best foot forward in that regard. "One of them, which is quite basic, is to collect the data and share the data with hiring managers," she explained. 

"I'm not advocating for quotas or for top-down forced [hiring policies] that dictate what the team makeup needs to look like from a gender perspective, but If your hiring managers don't have awareness of what the makeup of the teams look like, how can they be part of the evolution we want to inspire here? So collect the data and share the data." 

She added that employers should also strive to find and nurture cohorts of like-minded women within their studios by establishing development programs that allow women from different disciplines to connect. "Maybe there's one female engineer on Team A and two female animators on Team B and one female designer on Team F, way over there," Juinio continued. "But do they know each other? Do they have opportunities to meet and connect? I think really looking to foster connection and support and this sense of community will really help women to be stronger." 

Related:The Persona 5 series has sold over 13 million copies

Marty agreed and noted how, when she worked at Warner Bros. Montreal, she kickstarted a Slack channel called 'Women of Warner' to unite women from different disciplines. 

"At the time, developers were very separated from QA‚Äîbecause QA was on the publishing side and handling all of the titles for the company, while devs were just at Warner Montreal," she recalled. 

"But I said 'no, anybody who worked at Warner Montreal should be part of this and it allowed a lot of the women in QA to connect with devs and ask them questions. It's so simple and it's free and it's the most basic thing, but allowing that connection [helps]." 

Marty added that companies should be proactive in identifying women who want to pursue leadership opportunities to figure out how to meet their specific needs. "Not everybody wants a leadership role," she added. "Some people are happy to remain individual contributors and experts, but if you don't ask the question you'll never know. So identify them and then ask 'what's the path [for this person]? What does that look like?' and start building."

item.title: How Lego Designed Its Authentic Nintendo Game Boy Model
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Lego's brick-built Game Boy replica is bound to be one of the most popular gift ideas for retro gaming enthusiasts this holiday. The 421-piece recreation of Nintendo's legendary 1989 handheld is wonderfully designed, fun to build, and looks great on a display shelf. It comes with two buildable games, The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening and Super Mario Land, which can be loaded into the handheld's Game Pak slot. Swappable lenticular screens recreate moments from each game as well as the Game Boy's boot screen. The $60 price tag makes it one of the most affordable Lego sets made for adults. The Lego Game Boy launched October 1 at the Lego Store and major retailers, including Amazon, Walmart, and Target.

I spoke with Lego Group Senior Designer Carl Merriam over email about the design of the newest Lego Nintendo display model. Questions and answers are attributed to GameSpot and Lego, respectively.

GameSpot: I've always been fascinated by the logistics of designing a LEGO set. How do you start? How do designers determine how many pieces each build should have? How do you choose the shapes and sizes of the pieces? Did the Game Boy go through multiple iterations before finding the right design? Can you provide a general overview of how a designer gets from the idea to a finished product?

LEGO: We start with an idea. For the LEGO Game Boy the idea was: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs make a LEGO set celebrating the original Nintendo Game Boy.‚Äù From there we built several different versions using existing LEGO Bricks. While doing that we determined that we would need a few new LEGO elements. We started developing the new LEGO elements and built many, many, many more versions of the LEGO Game Boy. Eventually we found combinations of pieces that looked like the reference, are stable when built and most importantly are fun to put together.

GameSpot: Does the LEGO Game Boy set use any unique pieces not found in other LEGO sets?

LEGO: We developed a special 4x4 curved LEGO brick for the corner with the speaker, as well as a 6x8 tile for the back plate and a 2x4 bracket to build in the buttons. Many of the other pieces were existing bricks. The start and select buttons are tires, which originally launched in 1969, the A and B buttons are minifigure hats, AND we even managed to include a classic 2x4 brick inside.

GameSpot: What did Nintendo bring to this design, in terms of knowledge, advice, and secrets?

LEGO: We work closely with Nintendo on all LEGO Nintendo products, and the Game Boy was no different. One of the most fun parts was working with Nintendo on what easter eggs to include and what game screens to replicate from Super Mario Land and The Legend of Zelda: Links Awakening. Nintendo provided both design input on the build, as well as reference images of the actual hardware components.

GameSpot: How important was it to make this set not only look like the Game Boy, but also feel like an accurate replica of a handheld device? At the same time, aspects such as visible studs on the D-pad make it evident this is a LEGO set. I imagine it's critical for a replica to still look like a LEGO set?

LEGO: During the development of this set, we built many versions with different levels of functionality. Given the size of the original Game Boy, we were presented with the opportunity to figure out creative ways to include physical functions into the build. During this process, we found that it was possible to make all the controls interactive. My attention then shifted to trying to replicate the haptics of the actual hardware. I started to focus on each of the controls, the buttons, dials and power switch ‚Äî testing different versions of the build to find the closest simulation of the sensation of holding a real Game Boy.

The studs on the D-pad are included for two reasons:

1. We like to include studs to add LEGO DNA, so you can see it is a LEGO model.

2. That combination of LEGO bricks (with the studs showing) allows the D-pad to be able to tilt as it does on the real Game Boy. Recessing it into the LEGO Game Boy and adding tiles to cover the studs was one of the possible design choices, but that would remove the functionality.

GameSpot: Are the buildable cartridges the same size as actual Game Boy games? If so, can the cartridge slot hold real games?

LEGO: Unfortunately not. The real Game Pak is slightly too big to fit into the LEGO Game Boy set.

GameSpot: Were Link's Awakening and Super Mario Land always the cartridge choices, or were other games in the running? What's your personal favorite Game Boy game?

LEGO: After looking at several different games, we landed on these two first-party games to celebrate our longstanding partnership with Nintendo.

Link‚Äôs Awakening is my personal favorite Game Boy game. I have a vivid memory of calling the Nintendo hotline for some help getting the Hookshot while playing it.

GameSpot: What's the smallest detail on this set that you're most proud of? What was the biggest challenge you faced?

LEGO: I used all my powers as both a veteran LEGO designer and a lifelong LEGO fan to make this set as excellent as possible, so there are lots of favorite things to choose from. If I have to pick just one... it has to be the power switch function. While working on this set, I focused on replicating all the haptics of the real Game Boy as closely as possible. I tried to make all the buttons press-able and the dials turn-able, but getting that power switch to slide and click like the real one... that is my favorite feature.

The biggest challenge I faced was trying to replicate the dimensions of the real Game Boy. The closest LEGO dimensions to the form factor of the real Game Boy are: 11 studs wide by 18 studs long by 3.6 studs deep. Dimensions for LEGO Bricks tend to be in even numbers, so finding the right combination of elements to put the screen and screen surrounding in the center of the device was a real brain teaser.

GameSpot: Besides the Game Boy, what's your favorite LEGO Nintendo set?

LEGO: It has to be the LEGO Super Mario Desert Pokey (71363). I love this set, it is so amazing how well it replicates the interaction with the Desert Pokey from the Super Mario games in real life.

The Lego Game Boy is the eighth officially licensed Nintendo building set designed for adults and the second to release in 2025. In May, Lego launched a very cool 1,972-piece Mario Kart display model for $170.

Retro Nintendo fans should also check out the Super Mario World: Mario & Yoshi Lego set. This 1,215-piece model is built to resemble the Super Nintendo's 16-bit pixel art. The interactive sprites of Mario and Yoshi look fantastic. Released exactly one year before the Game Boy, Super Mario World: Mario & Yoshi retails for $130 but is on sale for $105 at Amazon.

item.title: Arc Raiders Straight Record Quest Guide

Arc Raiders is filled with quests that require you to get things back up and running topside to help those down below get prepared to take the world back from the ARC. One such quest called Straight Record comes from Celeste, who sends you topside in the Dam Battlegrounds to turn on an old EMP. This task will require you to not only find the old EMP but also turn on multiple switches to get it going again--so if you're struggling to find them, we've got you covered. Here's how to complete the Straight Record quest in Arc Raiders.

Where to find the old EMP trap for the Straight Record quest

Completing the Straight Record quest does not require you to extract. As such, feel free to spawn into the raid using a free loadout to avoid any loss of resources in the event that you perish from enemies or other players while trying to get it finished.

Your first goal in Straight Record is to find the old EMP trap in the Victory Ridge area. This spot is located in the upper left side of the map just slightly southwest of the West Broken Ridge POI. Reaching this location shouldn't prove too difficult, though you may need to fend off a raider or two also doing the quest--or work together, if that's more your speed.

When you arrive, you'll spot a tall, thin machine with wires wrapped around it. This is the old EMP, and you'll simply need to interact with it to discover that it's not powered on yet. This will begin the next part of the quest.

Where to find the power switches for the Straight Record quest

There are three power switches you'll need to turn on before you can activate the old EMP. They're all close by, though, so you won't need to venture far to get them turned on.

The first switch can be found on a small cliff just north of the old EMP. You can walk around the outside of the cliff to reach it. Interact with it to turn it on.

The second switch is located just east of the old EMP on a collapsed structure. Use the debris here to climb up onto the second floor of the structure and find the switch, then turn it on.

The third switch requires you to head south of the old EMP just a little way. You'll find it directly next to a tree, so go ahead and turn it on.

With all of the switches found, you're ready to return to the old EMP. Interact with it once more to complete the quest.

With the quest complete, you can decide whether you'd like to go loot some more before extracting, or simply head to the North Complex Elevator to the northeast to get the hell out of dodge before any other players come try to take you out. Either way, don't let your guard down, raider!

item.content:encoded:

Most quests in Arc Raiders send you to complete a couple of tasks on any given map, but a few quests require you to traverse long distances to clear multiple requirements. Perhaps the most substantial of these is A First Foothold, which asks you to visit four locations across Blue Gate. Each of these is on a completely different side of the map (north, east, south, west). It's a lengthy quest that may prove dangerous, but we're here to help you figure it out.

Luckily, you won't need to visit all of these locations in a single raid, meaning you can always knock out the tasks across multiple visits if you prefer. You also don't need to extract for any of them to count, so feel free to handle this with a free loadout that you don't mind losing if things get hairy.

Here's how to finish all four requirements to complete A First Foothold.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Stabilize the observation deck near the Ridgeline
  • Enable the comms terminal near the Olive Grove
  • Nail down the roof plates on the Raider structure near Trapper's Glade
  • Rotate the satellite dishes on the church roof, north of the Data Vault

Stabilize the observation deck near the Ridgeline

The Ridgeline is located on the eastern portion of Blue Gate. This area is far removed from much of the mayhem that happens in the center of the map, making it one of the safer sections you'll visit during this quest.

The observation deck is found along the very outer rim of the map. Interact with one of the prompts here to stabilize the structure. Afterward, you can be on your way to your next objective.

Enable the comms terminal near the Olive Grove

The Olive Grove is located in the southern portion of Blue Gate. This area can get pretty active, as it's a popular farming area for olives, as its name suggests. Be careful and perhaps try to be friendly to any nearby raiders.

You can find the comms terminal on a platform in the western section of this POI. Interact with the computer here to complete the objective, then head off to the next spot.

Nail down the roof plates on the Raider structure near Trapper's Glade

The Trapper's Glade is located in the western portion of Blue Gate. This area is fairly unsafe due to the Bombardier and various other ARC that patrol through here. Be very careful--sneaking around if necessary--as you approach.

You can find the Raider structure among plenty of trees here, just below the word "Trapper's" on the map. Crawl on top of the structure and interact with the roof to nail down the plates, then take off toward your next objective.

Rotate the satellite dishes on the church roof, north of the Data Vault

The church roof is located in the northern portion of Blue Gate. Due to its location far up in the hills away from much of the chaos down below, you should find things are pretty quiet. At most, you could run into a fellow raider or two doing the quest, so maybe wave and be friendly if needed.

You'll need to crawl on top of a church here using the scaffolding along the sides. At the top, interact with the satellite to complete the task. If necessary, head off to any remaining objectives. Otherwise, you'll be done with A First Foothold.

Blizard has announced the official dates for when tickets will go on sale for BlizzCon next year, when it returns to the Anaheim Convention Center in September 2026. Early-Bird tickets will go on sale starting November 7 at 9 AM PT / 12 PM ET, and are priced at $250 for both days of the fan expo. This includes taxes and fees, and it comes with commemorative in-game items as a bonus.

These tickets will be sold while supplies last, after which, Blizzard will sell a standard ticket weekend pass for $290 starting November 18. This is $10 cheaper than the standard tickets sold for BlizzCon 2023, and it also offers full two-day weekend admission to BlizzCon on both Saturday and Sunday.

Fans looking to upgrade their experience can purchase a $500 ticket to BlizzCon Charity Night, an exclusive event with Blizzard developers, artists, and community representatives. This does not include access to the convention, and proceeds will go to the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

There'll also be the Darkmoon Faire After Hours experience, an optional add-on that grants you entry to an exclusive three-hour event on the Saturday of BlizzCon. Priced at $90 all-in, a BlizzCon Pass is required to purchase this add-on. All passes will be sold through TIXR.

What to expect from BlizzCon 2026

BlizzCon is where Blizzard makes its biggest announcements, and while the company is keeping things quiet for now, it has confirmed that it is planning some "major" reveals during its opening ceremony. Beyond that, the convention will see the return of the Blizzard Arcade, developer panels, and hands-on gameplay sessions for games like World of Warcraft, Diablo IV, Overwatch 2, Hearthstone, and Diablo Immortal. Presumably, these titles will have new content revealed for them, explaining their presence on the showfloor.

Last year, Blizzard said that it had decided to not hold a BlizzCon 2024 "after careful consideration." The show has been held on and off again throughout the 2020s, due in part to the COVID-19 pandemic. BlizzCon 2022 was a digital-only presentation, while BlizzCon 2023 was a traditional in-person event. Since then, Blizzard has skipped in-person BlizzCon events for 2024 and 2025.

item.title: Arc Raiders - All Scrappy Upgrades And Where To Get The Items
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Resources are everything in Arc Raiders, which is why it's important to have a constant influx of materials to keep you thriving. That's where Scrappy comes in. This little rooster hangs out at Speranza and gathers resources for you passively, which you can then claim each time you finish a raid. You'll want to make the most of this helpful little guy by upgrading him so he can provide you with faster accumulation of materials. Here's what you need to know about all of Scrappy's upgrades and where to find the items needed for them.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • All Scrappy upgrade tiers and requirements

    • Level 2

  • Where to find all Scrappy upgrade items

    • Where to find Prickly Pears
    • Where to find Mushrooms

All Scrappy upgrade tiers and requirements

Scrappy has five tiers, with each upgrade providing faster production of resource materials. When you reach his max level of 5, you'll be able to keep important materials flowing in consistently after each raid, which will help you stay capable of crafting new items for future runs.

Level 1

  • Unlocked automatically

Level 2

  • Dog Collar x1

Level 3

  • Lemons x3
  • Apricots x3

Level 4

  • Prickly Pears x6
  • Olives x6
  • Cat Bed x1

Level 5

  • Mushrooms x12
  • Apricots x12
  • Very Comfortable Pillow x3

Where to find all Scrappy upgrade items

Some of the items needed to upgrade Scrappy can take quite a while to find. Luckily, we've got the info you need to help you round them all up.

Where to find a Dog Collar and Cat Bed

Dog Collars and Cat Beds are fairly common drops compared to the other unique items needed, so you should round one up relatively quickly. You can find Dog Collars in residential areas on any map.

Some places that have a high probability of spawning them include the Ruby Residence and Pale Apartments in the northwest area of Dam Battlegrounds, and the Grandioso Apartments on the western side of Buried City.

Where to find a Very Comfortable Pillow

Similar to Dog Collars and Cat Beds, Very Comfortable Pillows can be found in residential areas. Refer to the photos above for good residential areas.

However, you may have more luck seeking them out in medical POIs. Two common spots to round these up include the Testing Annex in Dam Battlegrounds and the Hospital in Buried City.

Where to find Lemon, Apricot, and Olive trees

Lemons, Apricots, and Olives grow on trees across multiple maps. While you can certainly find Lemons and Apricots early by looking hard enough in the swampy areas of Dam Battlegrounds, you'll have a much easier time collecting all of these fruits on the Blue Gate map.

Lemon and Apricot trees can be found in the Village POI in the northern section of Blue Gate. This is a high traffic area, though, and the trees are mostly found in the village's center, meaning you may be spotted by patrolling ARC or other raiders. Approach this location with caution. Try to get in, snag what you need, and get out. Don't forget to kick the trees when applicable to drop extra fruits!

Olives can be found very easily in the Olive Grove area in the south of the map. Simply wander around this area searching the ground beneath the trees and kicking them when possible to drop additional Olives. You may also spot a few Apricot or Lemon trees in this area, making it a great spot for obtaining all these fruits at once.

As a side note, even if you're just on Scrappy's second-tier upgrade, make sure you stock up on a lot of Apricots while looting, as you'll need a lot more for his fourth-tier upgrade.

Where to find Prickly Pears

Prickly Pears are found near cacti, which can be found all over the maps in Arc Raiders. However, the best spots to search tend to be on the outer perimeters of the Dam Battlegrounds and Buried City maps, especially in the northern part of the former and all along the southern section of the latter.

You'll find numerous cactus spawns all across these outer sections, though actual Prickly Pear spawns are far less generous. Just keep at it, though, and you'll eventually find enough to make Scrappy happy.

Where to find Mushrooms

Mushrooms are likely to be the hardest resource to find for Scrappy's upgrades. These spawn in damp areas across multiple maps, but they're quite contested since everyone needs so many of them. It's best to be ready for a fight if you're searching in any area known for Mushroom spawns.

Generally, your best bet for finding Mushrooms will be on Dam Battlegrounds. You can catch them growing on trees throughout the swamp area on the left side of the map, but some better locations to look include the Wreckage in the southeast and inside the Water Treatment Center.

For the Water Treatment Center, head to the interior hallways and follow the pipes. Mushrooms will often be growing beneath or on these pipes, so you're likely to find at least one per visit if you're searching thoroughly enough. Again, however, remember you may run into other raiders here, so don't let your guard down.

item.title: Disneyland's best ride is coming to Fortnite this week as part of a "playful" 70th anniversary "experience"
item.content:encoded:
I might not be massively into Fortnite these days, but if there's one thing guaranteed to pique my interest in anything, it's a Disney Haunted Mansion crossover. So as someone who's been obsessed with the now five-and-a-half-decade-old theme park attraction since the age of three, it looks like a reinstall is on the cards. Epic has announced a "playful" new Fortnite experience celebrating Disneyland's 70th anniversary is launching 6th November.

Hints that something Haunted Mansion was afoot first surfaced on the official Disneyparks Instagram feed, which shared an image of the attraction's iconic stretch room paintings, reimagined to include Fortnite characters like Peely and Fishstick. "This lobby has no windows and no doors", read the caption, suggesting the real chills, as they say, would come later.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

And that 'later' didn't take long to arrive. Before we could even finish pondering why all this missed Halloween, Disney and Epic provided an answer: simply, there's more to it than those 999 happy haunts. The Haunted Mansion is coming to Fortnite this week as part of the newly announced Disneyland Game Rush; a "playful, limited-time" Fortnite Creative island "experience" designed to celebrate Disneyland's 70th Anniversary.

Starting in a Disneyland-inspired hub - featuring a central sculpture modelled on Sleeping Beauty Castle and a skyline of familiar resort landmarks - up to 11 players can branch off to explore one of seven "quick-play" mini-games. Haunted Mansion fans get Scavenger Haunt, Space Mountain is represented by Rocket Race, there's the Matterhorn: Slip-and-Climb, Guardians of the Galaxy ‚Äì Mission: Sneak Out, Star Wars: Stormtrooper Showdown, Indiana Jones: Tomb Runner, and WEB-Slingers: Spider-Bot Blasters. By completing these mini-games, it's possible to unlock island-specific cosmetics, so if I don't get to manifest my head in a hatbox, I'll be wildly disappointed.

Speaking of disappointment, I was all ready to be a grump about the fact Scavenger Hunt wasn't exactly the massive Haunted Mansion Fortnite blow-out I was envisaging after seeing that original Disneyparks post, but IGN has screenshots of Disneyland Game Rush - complete with waltzing dinner party ghosts and, YES, a hatbox - and it actually looks pretty neat.

Disneyland Game Rush launches on 6th July (you can find it using island code 4617-4819-8826) and serves as something of a prelude for the main event. Announced in February last year, Disney has partnered with Epic to create an "expansive and open games and entertainment universe connected to Fortnite" which - judging by its concept art - looks very much like a virtual theme park. Perhaps we'll have more news on that soon.

item.title: Marvel Will Continue Collaborating With Insomniac Games ‚ÄúFor Many Years to Come‚Äù

It's no secret that Marvel Games and PlayStation's Insomniac Games have a good relationship. We wouldn't have three Marvel's Spider-Man games and one upcoming Marvel's Wolverine game without a strong relationship between both companies, and in a new interview with Game Informer, we got a bit more insight into just how good Marvel feels about the relationship.

General manager of Marvel Games, Haluk Mentes, spoke at length about the importance of Marvel Games and the studios it collaborates with being aligned in their approach to making anything with Marvel characters, and making something that is authentically Marvel.

"The challenge is more complex: authenticity doesn't necessarily mean one-to-one fidelity to source or reference material, whether it's comics or animation or movies. It's much deeper in that we allow our collaborating teams to reimagine 'familiar yet original' incarnations of our characters based on their own creative DNA...We absolutely do not want to be derivative. Otherwise, what's the point of working with some of the best talent out there?"

"There‚Äôs a great sense of responsibility at play here: Marvel is an almost 90-year-old creative brand, yet it‚Äôs as fresh as ever because during all that time, each new generation grew up with Marvel, ultimately became creators and left their mark, and then passed the torch to the next generation."

"We also actively seek collaborators that want to take on the same mantle. As is usually the case, once we complete a project together, they, too, become ‚ÄúMarvel.‚Äù Marvel‚Äôs Wolverine with our dear friends at Insomniac Games is perhaps the epitome of this philosophy. We have been working together for more than a decade and developed such a shorthand across multiple Marvel‚Äôs Spider-Man games that when the time finally came to bring Logan back in spectacular and visceral fashion, it was obvious to everyone on our team that Insomniac was the perfect choice. item.title: Nintendo Foresees More Acquisitions in Its Future
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo has revealed that making more studio acquisitions will form a key part of its business strategy in future, so it looks like we can expect to see more Nintendo subsidiaries popping up before too long.

In a supplementary document accompanying the Japanese gaming giant's latest financial results, Nintendo president Shuntaro Furukawa sets out how he intends to strengthen Nintendo's "business foundation".

Part of those efforts, Furukawa says, will be "acquiring development companies to make them subsidiaries", as well as "augmenting [Nintendo's] development facilities", all of which is intended to help "strengthen the internal game development organization" within Nintendo.

Other initiatives Nintendo is putting into effect to strengthen its business end include "building software assets in non-game entertainment", i.e. pursuing opportunities related to other media, and "maintaining and expanding [its] relationship with consumers".

Some of Nintendo's existing subsidiaries include the likes of Luigi's Mansion 3 and Mario Strikers: Battle League developer Next Level Games, as well as Monolith Soft, the studio responsible for the Xenoblade series of RPGs.

The Japanese gaming giant also owns Retro Studios, the developer to whom work on Metroid Prime 4 was handed back in 2019. The hotly-anticipated first-person shooter is set to finally launch next month.

Some studios that technically aren't Nintendo subsidiaries, despite frequently working with the publisher, include Kirby's HAL Laboratory, Mario Tennis developer Camelot Software Planning, and Masahiro Sakurai's Sora Limited, all of which could be potential contenders for Nintendo's next acquisition.

Nintendo's pledge to acquire more developers comes after initial numbers indicate that the Switch 2, which was released back in June, is a roaring success for the company. Reportedly, Nintendo has asked its manufacturing partners to produce 25 million units of the console by March.

The news also comes after Doug Bowser, who was appointed as president of the company's American division in 2019, will step down at the end of the year. His role will be taken by Devon Pritchard, who's currently serving as NOA's revenue and marketing executive VP.

item.title: PlayStation Portal Cloud Streaming Update Lets You Stream Without Your PS5 Today
item.content:encoded:
Sony has released a new update for its PlayStation Portal device that allows you to stream PS5 games without needing your main console handy, but you'll have to be a PlayStation Plus Premium member to use it.

As outlined in a new PlayStation Blog post, the update, which entered beta last year, is being released today at 6pm Pacific (so you'll need to wait until 2am tomorrow morning if you're in the UK like me).

If you're a PS Plus Premium member, you can now stream PS5 games from your own library; not every game is supported, but Sony says the feature is available for "thousands of PS5 games", including the likes of Astro Bot, Final Fantasy VII Rebirth, and the recently-released Ghost of Yotei.

Prior to the update, you could only stream games to your PlayStation Portal if you were near your corresponding PS5, but you can now do so anywhere with a high-speed internet connection.

You'll also find a brand new home screen for the Portal as part of this update, with a brand new dedicated Cloud Streaming menu that shows which games can be streamed to your device without needing to connect to a PS5.

As well as the new Cloud Streaming stuff, the latest update also brings new features for both Remote Play and Cloud Streaming, including 3D audio support, a new passcode lock system to protect your Portal, and a network status screen that displays connection quality.

Cloud streaming additions include support for in-game purchases, new accessibility options, and the chance to receive game invitations from friends who are playing the same game as you. What a time to be alive, eh?

This latest PlayStation Portal update will be released today at 6pm Pacific/9pm Eastern, and it arguably brings the device one step closer to that dedicated Sony handheld some fans have been clamoring for. Stay tuned for more.
